Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery ovoid neck-amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of part of horse and rider to right; rider wearing chiton in added red with added white dots on decorated borders and possibly holding spear; of horse hindquarters with red, back, and white dots on rein remain.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd is also published in Mommsen, H., Der Affecter. Mainz 1975, 93, no. 37, who suggests that the figure was situated under the handle of a large amphora.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 241, no. B122)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0033) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 97, pl. III, no. 21)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
